item.text: The items described here represent special clothing types ormost part, clothing choice is based on character concept. It is assumed that a character owns a reasonable wardrobe of the sorts of clothes that fit their lifestyle. Sometimes, however, a character might need something out of the ordinary. When that's the case, they will have to purchase it like any other piece of gear. Clothes have three effects on game mechanics: one on Presence checks, one on Stealth checks, and one on environmental factors. First, clothing is part of a disguise.

See the Presence skill description for more on how appropriatefirearms, body armor, and small objects. Tightly tailored clothing imposes a penalty on an attempt to conceal an object; clothing purposely tailored to conceal objects provides a bonus. Clothing also includes worn accessories, such as holsters, sheathes, and armor.

An outfit of clothing represents everything a character needs toshoes or boots, socks or stockings, and any necessary belt or suspenders. The clothes a character wears does not count against the weight limit for encumbrance. Each outfit has a level that is appropriate for a given temperature range (very hot, hot, mild, cold, or very cold), and the wearer can remove layers or roll up cuffs to make it acceptable, if not completely comfortable, for the next higher range. The price listed is for the base set of clothes, high-fashion clothing can be exponentially expensive.

Clothing can also hold equipment. As a general rule, a set ofthat is tiny or smaller, per pocket. Different styles and clothing configurations can change this, up to the GM's discretion. Clothing itself, and any items or equipment that is carried within clothing is not counted against a character's total carrying capacity. Any weapons carried within a pocket without a holster or sheath, are considered waistband carried.

Standard A standard module contains most of the core features that most would find useful, leaving out only a few specialized programs. This module provides a +3 to all bonuses listed in the module description unless specified otherwise and takes up 2 storage slots.

Caltrops are four-pronged steel spikes designed so that one prong scatters caltrops on the ground to injure opponents, or at least slow them down. One bag of twenty-five caltrops covers a single 5' square. Each time a creature moves through a square containing caltrops at any rate greater than 15 feet a turn or each round a creature spends fighting in such an area, the caltrops make a touch attack roll (BAB +0). A caltrop deals 1 point of damage on a successful hit, and the injury reduces foot speed to 2 Combat Points per 5' (a successful Treat Injury check [TN15] or one day's rest removes this penalty). Improvised versions of this weapon include jacks and d4 gaming dice. These improvised weapons do not work on vehicles, however. A running creature (Moving more than 30' per turn) must immediately stop if it steps on a caltrop. See the avoid hazard stunt for the effect of caltrops on vehicles.

Ball bearings are little metal balls, often used to maintain the ball bearings covers a single 5' square thoroughly. Each time a creature moves through a square containing ball bearings or each round a creature spends fighting in such an area, the character makes a Reflex Saving Throw [TN16] or be knocked prone. Improvised versions of this weapon include marbles.
Binoculars are useful for watching opponents, wild game, and
Standard Standard binoculars reduce the range penalty for 10'). Using binoculars for Perception checks takes five times as long as making the check unaided.
Night Vision Binoculars Night vision binoculars function the same users looking through them see as if they were using night vision goggles.

A flare is a bright chemical burning reaction in a stick, that projects light in a 40' circle from itself, and lasts for 1 hour per flare. Once activated, it can't be turned off or reused. It can also be used to immediately set any flammable material or substances ablaze.

This device contains several different screwdrivers, a knife ruler, scissors, tweezers, and wire cutters. The whole thing unfolds into a handy pair of pliers. A multipurpose tool can lessen the penalty for making Craft (Mechanical), Craft (Electronics), Craft (Structural), Demolitions, or Disable Device checks without appropriate tools to −4 instead of the normal −6. The tool is useful for certain tasks as determined by the GM, but may not be useful in all situations.

This portable apparatus uses a chemical spray to extinguish small chemicals to put out a fire in a 10'-by-10' area and contains enough material for two such uses. It does 1d4 Cold damage when sprayed.
Handcuffs are restraints designed to lock two limbs—normally the human or other creature that has an appropriate body structure.
Steel These heavy-duty cuffs have Hardness 10, 10 HP, Break check [TN35] to remove without the key.

Road Atlas Road atlases are available for the entire Country and also be purchased for most major metropolitan areas and detail every street in the entire region.

For the cigar connoisseur or one who simply likes to strike wood listed is for one hundred boxes of twenty matches.
This lightweight sleeping bag rolls up compactly. It can keep a bonus on Fortitude Saving Throws against the effects of cold weather.
A parachute is a device used to slow down an object in free fall but all stop fall damage from heights greater than 100' and reduce falling damage by 1 die per round spent descending.
Military Parachute A typical circular canopy used for static line being designed for simplicity and reliability. These parachutes fall straight down.

Sports Parachute A rectangular aerobatic parachute. Consumer emergency visibility, but a character can purchase a darker parachute at request. Sports parachutes allow a character to glide at 200 feet per round forward as they fall, as well as make a turn after moving 100 feet.
A battering ram is rather self explanatory, a heavy metal ram character is considered to have +4 STR.

The band-it is an elastic sleeve that is placed on prisoners leg When activated, it sends a strong electrical pulse through the wearer's body, that incapacitate the person wearing it. When Activated, the band-it, the wearer of the band-it must make a Fortitude Saving Throw [TN17] or be paralyzed for 1d4 rounds. The band-it comes with one remote that has a 200 foot range.

A spotting scope is a highly magnified scope that is used for in acquiring a target. When used by a spotter who is within hearing range of a sniper, and is able to see the same targets the sniper can see using the spotting scope, the sniper gains a bonus to all ranged attacks equal to the spotter's ranged attack bonus, as long as the spotter is spotting for that sniper. Spotting for a sniper uses all of the character's combat points per round. Only one sniper can take advantage of a spotter and their scope at a time.

Hearing protection are plugs, earmuffs, or molded inserts that firing firearms or working with heavy machinery. As a general rule, hearing loss due to gunfire is not modeled in Ops and Tactics, but wearing hearing protection can protect against unexpected loud noises. Only basic protection can be worn under helmets.
Basic Hearing Protection Encompasses foam plugs, wax balls, and Will Saving Throws against being deafened.

Active Hearing Protection Encompasses thin electronic active it hears loud noises, but otherwise allows for the wearer to hear as normal through microphones and speakers in the earmuffs. When worn, the wearer will automatically succeed against all Will Saving Throws against being deafened, and the user can hear as normal.

item.text: Food and drink range from fine wine with a nice Italian meal torepresentative of what a character would encounter out in the field. All food provides Nutritional Value (NV). A character must consume at least 8 NV worth of food every day to sustain themselves.

box.text: Generally, a GM can assume that their players are eating and consumption if they are within any kind of civilization that has some kind of established way to receive sustenance. This can range from fast food restaurants all the way to a place to purchase ingredients and make home cooked meals. GMs should only worry about Nutritional Values, starvation, and thirst if the players do not have a readily available way to continuously consume meals. Also, it is assumed that character are spending some of their non-received salaries on food, and do not have to spend any of their given incomes on food, unless they otherwise want to purchase something specific.

A MRE (Meal, Ready to Eat) is a self contained individual field from organized food facilities. They are also popular with survivalists and hikers for their compact size and filling nature. MREs come in various versions, suitable for carnivores, omnivores, and herbivores.
Military The Military MRE has enough food to feed a single
A trail ration is a mix of high calorie content foods, usually 12. Trail rations will feed a character 1 NV.
A food bar is a solid baked bar, consumed by people on the go as will feed a character 2 NV.

Snack foods encompass a multitude of foods you'd expect to find biscuits, cookies, cakes, pastries, snack mixes and various miscellaneous candies. A pack of snack food will feed a character for anywhere from 1 NV to 3 NV, depending on what kind of snack food they find. The price listed is for 10 packs. It is recommended that a GM roll 1d3 to determine the NV of the pack of snack food.
A candy bar is a bar, usually coated in chocolate, that contains toffee. They are poor in nutrients, but taste very good. The price listed is for a box of 15. A candy bar will feed a character 1 NV.
These are sausages that don't require refrigeration, usually made sausage and 0.2 lb of sausage will feed a character 2 NV.
This is bread in a sealed plastic pouch, capable of keeping freshness. The price listed is for a 4 pack of pouch bread. Each pouch will feed a character 3 NV.
Aged cheddar, aged gouda, and parmigiano reggiano are some of the without refrigeration. The price listed is for 2 lbs of cheese, and 0.2 lb of cheese will feed a character 3 NV.
These are a multitude of various grains, such as rice, oats, boiled with water and eaten with a variety of additions. The price listed is for 20 lbs, and 0.5 lb will feed a character 3 NV.

Jerky is lean meat that has been trimmed of fat, cut into strips, made into jerky and is often carried by outdoorsmen, hikers, and campers as a source of low fat, high protein food. The packaging listed is for 6 bags. A single bag will feed a character 3 NV.

These are freeze dried instant noodles that come in a pack. They way, or they can be boiled with water, and the flavor package added for a simple, decently tasting meal, especially when coupled with dried vegetables. Due to their low cost, they can sustain someone for very low price, though they also lack in nutritional value. The price listed is for 4 packs of 10 each. A single pack of noodles will feed a character 4 NV.

These are freeze dried vegetables that have had moisture removed re-hydrated with water and consumed, or used as an ingredient. The price listed is for 6 lbs of mixed dried vegetables. 1 lb of re-hydrated vegetables will feed a character for 2 NV.
Fresh vegetables include fresh produce, fruit, and leafy greens. fresh vegetables will feed a character for 4 NV.
Fresh meat includes freshly slaughtered meats of various animals, and 1 lb of cooked fresh meat will feed a character for 4 NV.
Preserved meat includes meat that has been cured or smoked, and and 1 lb of preserved meat will feed a character for 5 NV.

This food encompasses both manufactured canning, where the food method where the food is preserved and placed into a glass jar. Canned food contents can vary greatly, anything from canned vegetables or meats to complete meals in a jar. Canned food will feed a character for anywhere from 1 NV to 8 NV, depending on the contents of the can. The price listed is for 10 cans. It is recommended that a GM roll 1d8 to determine the NV of the can.
Water is the transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly survive. This water is in 16 oz/2 units plastic bottles. The price listed is for 4 cases of 30 bottles of water per case.
Including both hot drinks like powdered cocoa and instant coffee, The price listed is for 5 boxes of 20 per box.
Canned soda is a 12 oz aluminum can. These serve as tasty drinks The price listed is for 4 cases of 12 cans per case.
Drinks are a wide variety of flavors and types, all having their Saving Throw [TN10 + number of servings they have had at a time], or become inebriated.

Beer Beer is the world's most widely consumed and probably oldest after water and tea. It is produced by the brewing and fermentation of sugars, typically derived from malted cereal grains, particularly barley and wheat. The price for beer is for a pack of 12. Each beer is a serving.
Brandy Brandy is a spirit produced by distilling wine, typically bottle, which contains about 30 servings.

Rum Rum is a distilled spirit made from sugarcane by-products of fermentation and distillation. It is used in drinks such as rum punch, mojitos, and pina coladas. The price listed is for a single bottle, which contains about 35 servings.

Vodka Vodka is a distilled beverage composed primarily of water made by distillation of fermented substances such as grains, potatoes, or sometimes fruits. The price listed is for a single bottle, which contains about 25 servings.

Liqueur Liqueur is a type of distilled alcoholic beverage that is sugar or sweetener added. It is often used for mixed drinks, but can be consumed by itself. Common liqueur examples include triple sec, schnapps, campari, chocolate liqueur, and amaretto. The price listed is for a single bottle, which contains about 20 servings.

A cigarette is a small roll of finely cut tobacco leaves wrapped tightly-rolled bundle of dried and fermented tobacco that is ignited so that its smoke may be drawn into the mouth. Smoking a pack of cigarettes or a single cigar causes 1 XHP damage per pack smoked. If a character loses their last non-lethal hit point due to smoking, they are nauseated for two hours and gain that hit point back after those two hours. The price listed is for a box of 20 cigars, or a carton of cigarettes, which contains 10 packs of 20 cigarettes each.

An electronic cigarette, also known as an e-cig, is a battery the lungs via a nicotine, propylene glycol, and flavoring mixture, designed to look like, but be much healthier than, cigarettes, as instead of smoke, it produces water vapor as its byproduct. Electronic cigarettes come in a massive array of flavors, from regular tobacco flavor to things such as mint, key lime pie, and even cinnamon roll. They take on a variety of appearances as well, from a thin cigarette like look, to a customizable tank and battery. The price listed is for a full kit that includes one tank, one battery with charging apparatus, and two flavors.

item.header: Pharmaceutical Drugs, Medical supplies and Poisons
item.text: Pharmaceutical drugs, also referred to as medicine, can bemedical diagnosis, cure, treatment, or prevention of disease. When using medicine, only the highest modifier applies.

box.text: An antibacterial is a compound or substance that kills or slows medication used specifically for treating viral infections. Both are used to combat against diseases, and grant a bonus to Fortitude Saving Throws toward disease. The cost of the drug is dependent on the actual Fortitude Saving Throw of the disease. The price listed is for three doses.

These medicines allow a character to ignore pain, and allow them effects wear off, the healing affect of the painkillers go with it. Painkillers can only be given to a character with at least 1 CHP. A player who has 0 or less CHP has suffered serious injuries and must receive medical attention and can not use painkillers. The price listed is for one dose, and each dose lasts for 1d3 hours. The dosage can come in the form of digestible pills or an injectable liquid.
These medicines promote the clotting of blood. They reduce the is for two doses.

Antiseptics are substances that are applied to destroy bonus to all Treat Injury checks when used, but the user must have at least 1 rank in the Treat Injury skill. The amount listed is for two doses.
Weak Antiseptic These include distilled spirits, as well as
Strong Antiseptics This includes iodine. They grant a +5 to Treat

Antidote is a substance used to counteract a specific poison. The and the character purchasing must know the specific poison used. The cost is for a single dose. The dosage can come in the form of digestable pills or an injectable liquid.

A cold pack is a strong plastic bag filled with water and a broken, it becomes very cold. It heals 2d3 damage per 10 minutes and can only be used to restore XHP that was lost by bludgeoning, fire, or non-lethal damage. The price listed is for eight packs, and the packs last for 1 hour.

Spray-on bandage is antiseptic and bandage all in one convenient damage per use and can only be used to restore XHP that was lost by by Slashing or Piercing damage. The price listed is for four, 20 dose bottles.

A tourniquet is a constricting device used to control bleeding on from extremity damage for 2d3 rounds, and reduces all bleed dice by 3 on that appendage for 2d3 minutes. Tourniquets can only be applied on arms or legs.

Field dressing are bandages used to control bleeding in general. Field dressings can also be used in conjunction with the Treat Injury skill when stopping bleeding. When used in this manner, they stop an additional 3 bleed damage per field dressing used, up to a maximum of 4 field dressing.

Poisons are chemical substances that can cause disturbances to molecular scale, when a sufficient quantity is absorbed by an organism. While nearly any substance ingested, injected, or inhaled into the body technically counts as a poison, the poisons listed here are specifically listed for their effects. The price listed is for 5 doses in a synthesized solid, liquid poison stored in a bottle, or a gas stored in a pressurized cylinder.

A genus of flowering plants that has long been used for fiber recreational drug. A character may smoke one dose of cannabis and roll a set of dice dependent on the potency. This roll is both the penalty to Will Saving Throws and their AGL modifier and a bonus to their XHP. The effect lasts for 5d12 minutes. Should the AGL penalty exceed the character's DEX score, it is treated as 0 until the drug's effect wears off. There are 50 doses in 0.1 lbs of cannabis. Any amount less than 50 doses is considered weightless.

The leafy part of the coca plant, chewed to reduce tiredness and hour. If a character is exhausted, they are now fatigued. If a character is fatigued, it takes half the amount of time to become well rested. Sold in packs of 16 leaves.

Cocaine is the processed version of the coca plant, used as a character may ingest, inject, or inhale one dose of cocaine (0.01 lb) to gain 5 additional Combat Points every round for 1 minute. The character may ingest, inject, or inhale subsequent doses to lengthen the time this bonus lasts by 1 minute, but it does not grant any additional Combat Points. After each dose is ingested, injected, or inhaled, a character immediately makes a Fortitude Saving Throw [TN25]. If a character fails this Saving Throw, they take CHP damage equal to the Combat Point bonus they received. The TN increases by 5 for each dose of Cocaine taken within 6 weeks of the first dose. There are 8 doses in 0.1 lbs of cocaine. Any amount less than 8 doses is considered weightless.

A pharmaceutical pill marketed as a treatment for ADHD, ADD, and which reduces Craft checks of 24 hours in length or more by 1d4 hours, and Craft checks of 1 week in length or more by 1d3 days. This effect lasts for one week. Adderall is packaged in a small bottle containing 10 pills.

An empathogenic drug that causes euphoria, a diminished sense of pill which grants a +2 bonus to all Reflex and Will Saving Throws. This bonus lasts for 30 minutes. After the effect wears off the character is considered Exhausted. A character can consume at least 4 units of water to halve the time it takes to recover from their exhaustion. MDMA is is packaged in a small bottle containing 10 pills.

These medicines allow a character to ignore pain, and allow them stronger versions of the over the counter painkillers and as such require proper documentation to possess. When the effects wear off, the healing effect of the opioid goes with it. Opioids can be given to a character with at least 1 CHP. Opioids will restore both CHP and XHP, but will always restore CHP before XHP. The price listed is for one dose and each dose lasts for 1d3 hours. After taking a single dose, the character takes 1 CON damage that heals normally.

These vary in presentation, type, and duration, but they all do takes a single dose of a hallucinogen, they take 3d3 WIS damage. This effect lasts 2d2 hours and the damage lasts as long as the effect.
